title: Hundreds of extra deaths on hottest day of the year
text:
The Office for National Statistics the figure may rise as more deaths are registered (Picture: PA)

There was a sharp rise in the number of deaths on Britain’s hottest day of the year, figures show.

On 25 July 2019, when temperatures reached a record breaking 38.7 °C, there were 1,473 deaths, which is about 300-400 more than the average in recent years, according to the Office for National Statistics (ONS).

The weather caused havoc on Britain’s transport system, with trains delayed and cancelled, after fears that they could derail in the heat.

The ONS has warned that the number of recorded deaths could rise, with the current data ‘provisional’.

While comparisons with previous years cannot yet be made using the recent summer’s data, the statisticians compared the number of deaths per day in summer 2018 with the five-year average (2013-18).

The ONS said: ‘The comparatively high number of deaths occur mainly on days that are defined as heatwaves by Public Health England (PHE) in their deaths relating to heatwaves report.

July 25 saw temperatures reach 38.7C in Cambridge, breaking the record for the highest temperature ever recorded (Picture: PA)

People across the country flocked to the beaches during the summer heatwave (Picture: Getty Images)

‘These spikes tended to be followed by periods of lower-than-average deaths.’

The body added: ‘This means that at a daily level, extreme heat seems to have an impact on the number of deaths, but across the summer period as a whole the number of deaths is similar to previous years.

‘This could be because the most vulnerable people, for example, those with pre-existing respiratory or cerebrovascular diseases are more susceptible to death during heatwaves.’

Even when taking into account the heatwaves, the effects of winter on mortality are consistently greater than summer, it added.
